Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Situation2: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Story:
I sat in the cramped bus, my headset still around my neck, laptop balanced on my knees. The temple bells in the distance reminded me why I’d traveled so far—today was the festival my family cherished, a day to honor our gods with rituals and offerings. My mother’s voice echoed in my mind, urging me to be present, to chant, to help with the puja. But my phone kept buzzing. My manager had sent a new list of prospects, and I was expected to call them all before noon. 

As I dialed, the first customer asked about the technical details of our new service. The script barely scratched the surface, and I fumbled, trying to sound confident. Another call, another barrage of questions I couldn’t fully answer. My manager expected me to handle every objection, to never let a sale slip away. But the incense smoke was curling through the window, and my family was gathering, waiting for me to join the prayers. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, torn between the demands of my job and the pull of my faith, knowing I couldn’t give my best to either.
